history.content:
I will ask you a question, then you should help me operate a MySQL database with SQL to answer the question.
You have to explain the problem and your solution to me and write down your thoughts.
After thinking and explaining thoroughly, every round you can choose to operate or to answer with the two specific tools provided.
If you should execute a SQL query, use the `execute_sql` function, Your SQL should be in one line.
Every time you can only execute one SQL statement. I will only execute the statement in the first SQL code block. Every time you write a SQL, I will execute it for you and give you the output.
If you are done operating, and you want to commit your final answer, then use the `commit_final_answer` function.
DO NOT use this tool unless you are sure about your answer. I expect an accurate and correct answer.
Your answer should be accurate. Your answer must be exactly the same as the correct answer.
If the question is about modifying the database, then after done operation, your answer field can be anything.
If your response cannot match any pattern I mentioned earlier, you will be judged as FAIL immediately.
You should always use the tools provided to submit your answer. Be careful not to write it in the content field.
Your input will be raw MySQL response, you have to deal with it by yourself.

Here are some useful workflows learned from past similar episodes, you can use them to help you complete the task:
Locate the row in the {table_name} where the {country} is \"Germany\". Set the value of the \"Shared elements\" column for that row to \"2\"

Given that the task involves extracting specific information from the Crest Whitestrips Products table, this workflow focuses on finding the length of use for specified products.
[step 1 description with {product_name} placeholder]
Find the row in the Crest Whitestrips Products table where the Model is equal to {product_name}.
[step 2 description with {product_name} placeholder]
Extract the value in the "Length of use" column for the row where the Model is {product_name}.

Create a table named Rankings with the following columns:\n- Rank (text)\n- Member Association (text)\n- Points (text)\n- Group stage (text)\n- Play-off (text)\n- AFC Cup (text)\n\nInsert the data into the Rankings table.

Given that the user needs to query the total number of medals for specific nations from the Medal Table, this workflow constructs and executes the query.
[step 1 description: Construct the query]
SELECT SUM(Gold + Silver + Bronze) AS Total_Medals FROM Medal_Table WHERE Nation IN ('{nation1}', '{nation2}', '{nation3}', '{nation4}');
[step 2 description: Execute the query]
PREPARE stmt FROM query;
EXECUTE stmt;
DEALLOCATE PREPARE stmt;

Given that the task requires comparing the length of use for two specific products, this workflow compares the "Length of use" for the two products.
[step 1 description with {product1_name} and {product2_name} placeholders]
Use the extract_whitestrips_info workflow to get the "Length of use" for {product1_name}.
[step 2 description with {product1_name} and {product2_name} placeholders]
Use the extract_whitestrips_info workflow to get the "Length of use" for {product2_name}.
[step 3 description]
Compare the "Length of use" values obtained for {product1_name} and {product2_name}.

Given that the table does not exist and column names need to be adjusted, this workflow creates the necessary table with correct column names.
[step 1 description: Create the table with the correct column names]
CREATE TABLE State_Parks_Table (
    Park_Name TEXT,
    County_or_Counties TEXT,
    Area_in_acres TEXT,
    Year_Established TEXT,
    Water_Body_s TEXT
);
[step 2 description: Insert the new park information into the table]
INSERT INTO State_Parks_Table (Park_Name, County_or_Counties, Area_in_acres, Year_Established, Water_Body_s)
VALUES ('Osage Hills State Park', 'Osage', '1, 100', '1936', '');

Given that the task is to update the points of a specific team in the standings table, this workflow automates the process.
[step 1] Connect to the database where the standings table is located.
[step 2] Execute an SQL update query to set the Points column to 6 for the row where Name is 'ESC Kempten II (N).'
[step 3] Commit the changes and close the database connection.

Insert a new row into the "Tour de France Winners by Stage" table with the values: {year}, {stage}, {start_of_stage}, {distance_km}, {category_of_climb}, {stage_winner}, {nationality}, {yellow_jersey}, {bend}. Verify the insertion by checking if the new row with values {year}, {stage}, {start_of_stage}, {distance_km}, {category_of_climb}, {stage_winner}, {nationality}, {yellow_jersey}, {bend} exists in the table.

Additional table information about the question: The name of this table is public_transportation_lines, and the headers of this table are Line,Colour,Route,Length,Stations.
Question: The Schottentour tram line, colored yellow, has a length of 11.2km (7mi) and passes through 20 stations. It is being added to the public transportation lines table.

function.name: execute_sql
function.arguments: {"query": "INSERT INTO public_transportation_lines (Line, Colour, Route, Length, Stations) VALUES ('Schottentour', 'yellow', 'Route Information', '11.2km (7mi)', '20');"}

function.name: execute_sql
function.arguments: {"query": "SELECT * FROM public_transportation_lines WHERE Line = 'Schottentour' AND Colour = 'yellow' AND Length = '11.2km (7mi)' AND Stations = '20';"}

function.name: commit_final_answer
function.arguments: {"answers": ["The Schottentour tram line has been successfully added to the public transportation lines table."]}

result.note: SingleAgentExecutionEngine: completed multi-turn execution via backend /interact.
